quest_title: Given function \(f(x)=\left(\cfrac{e^{2x} -1}{e^{2x} +1} \right)\) is
explanation_txt:
\[ f(x)=\cfrac{e^{2x} -1}{e^{2x} +1} \]

\[ \Rightarrow f(-x)=\cfrac{e^{-2x} -1}{e^{-2x} +1} =\cfrac{1-e^{2x} }{1+e^{2x} } \]

\[ \Rightarrow f(x)=-\cfrac{e^{2x} -1}{e^{2x} +1} =-f(x)\]

\(f(x)\) is an odd function.

Again \(f(x)=\cfrac{e^{2x} -1}{e^{2x} +1} \Rightarrow f'(x)=\cfrac{4e^{2x} }{(1+e^{2x} )^{2} } >0\, \forall \, n\in R\)

\( \Rightarrow \) \(f(x)\) is an increasing function.
question_plain_title: Given function is
explanation_plain_text:
is an odd function.

Again

is an increasing function.

quest_title: A body starts from rest and falls vertically through a height of 20 m. The time taken by the body to fall through last meter of fall is
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{h}=\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{gt}^{2}} \\ {\text { or, } \mathrm{t}=\sqrt{\cfrac{2 \mathrm{h}}{\mathrm{g}}}=\sqrt{\cfrac{2 \times 20}{10}}=2 \mathrm{sec}}\end{array}\)

\(\mathrm{t}^{1}=\sqrt{\cfrac{2 \mathrm{h}}{\mathrm{g}}}=\sqrt{\cfrac{2 \times 19}{10}}=1.95 \mathrm{sec}\)

\(\begin{aligned} \therefore \text { time to fall last meter } &=2-1.95 \\ &=0.05 \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: The magnifying power of a Galilean telescope is 5. The power of objective is +2D., then power of eye lens is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{a}}=+2 \mathrm{D}\)
\(\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{o}}=\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{a}}}=\cfrac{100}{2} \mathrm{cm}=50 \mathrm{cm}\)
\(\mathrm{m}=\cfrac{\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{o}}}{\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{e}}}\)
or, \(\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{e}}=\cfrac{50}{5}=-10 \mathrm{cm}\)
\(\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{e}}=\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{e}}}=\cfrac{1}{0.1}=-10 \mathrm{D}\)

quest_title: If \(A\) and \(B\) are disjoint sets, \(A \Delta B\) is:
explanation_txt:
\(A \Delta B = A\cup B - A\cap B \)

Since \(A\) and \(B\) are disjoint, \(A\cap B = \emptyset\). So, (a) is correct.

quest_title: 4gm of solid NaOH was dissolved in 100ml of water. The whole of this solution neutralize completely
explanation_txt:
Normality of NaOH = \(\cfrac{4/40}{0.1}\) = 1N

So, it requires 1N of 100 ml acid to neutralize NaOH solution.

Checking the options,

20 ml of 2.5M \(H_2SO_4\) = 20 ml of 5N \(H_2SO_4\) = 100 ml of 1N \(H_2SO_4\)

So, option B is correct.
question_plain_title: 4gm of solid NaOH was dissolved in 100ml of water. The whole of this solution neutralize completely
explanation_plain_text:
Normality of NaOH = = 1N

So, it requires 1N of 100 ml acid to neutralize NaOH solution.

Checking the options,

20 ml of 2.5M = 20 ml of 5N = 100 ml of 1N

So, option B is correct.

quest_title: The values of \(x\) and \(y\) for which the numbers \(3 + i x ^ { 2 } y\) and \(x ^ { 2 } + y + 4 i\) are conjugate complex can be
explanation_txt:
According to condition, \(3 - i x ^ { 2 } y = x ^ { 2 } + y + 4 i\)

\[\begin{array} { l } { \Rightarrow x ^ { 2 } + y = 3 \text { and } x ^ { 2 } y = - 4 \Rightarrow x = \pm 2 , y = - 1 } \\ { \Rightarrow ( x , y ) = ( 2 , - 1 ) \text { or } ( - 2 , - 1 ) } \end{array}\]

quest_title: While measuring the thermal conductivity of a liquid, we keep the upper part hot and lower part cool, so that
ans4_txt: It is easier and more convenient to do so
explanation_txt: Thermal conductivity is the measure of the ability of a material to conduct heat. To measure thermal conductivity of fluid, it is necessary to prevent heat transfer due to convection. For this, the upper part of vessel is made hot whereas the lower part of the vessel is kept cool.
question_plain_title: While measuring the thermal conductivity of a liquid, we keep the upper part hot and lower part cool, so that
explanation_plain_text: Thermal conductivity is the measure of the ability of a material to conduct heat. To measure thermal conductivity of fluid, it is necessary to prevent heat transfer due to convection. For this, the upper part of vessel is made hot whereas the lower part of the vessel is kept cool.
ans4_plain_text: It is easier and more convenient to do so

explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{\mathrm{r}_{2}}{\mathrm{r}_{1}}=\left(\cfrac{\mathrm{A}_{2}}{\mathrm{A}_{1}}\right)^{1 / 3}\)
or, \(\mathrm{r}_{2}=3 \times 10^{-15}\left(\cfrac{128}{16}\right)^{1 / 3}\)

quest_title: A square of side 3cm is located at a distance 25cm from a concave mirror of focal length 10cm. The centre of square is at the axis of the mirror and plane is normal to axis of mirror. The area enclosed by image of the square is
explanation_txt:
\(\quad\)\(v\) = \( \cfrac{fu}{u - f} = \cfrac{10\times 25}{25 - 10} = \cfrac{250}{15} = \cfrac{50}{3} \)cm

\(\quad\)\( \cfrac{v}{u} = \cfrac{I}{O} \)

\(\quad\)or, I = \( \cfrac{fu}{u - f} = \cfrac{24\times 60}{60 - 24} \) = 40cm

\(\quad\)\( \cfrac{1}{f} = \cfrac{1}{u} + \cfrac{1}{v} \)

\(\quad\)or, 0 = \( \cfrac{-du}{u^{2}} - \cfrac{dv}{v^{2}} \)

\(\quad\)or, \( \cfrac{dv}{du} = -\left(\cfrac{v}{u}\right)^{2}\)

\(\quad\)\(\therefore \) d\(v\) = \( \left(\cfrac{40}{60}\right)^{2}\)\(\times \)9

\(= 4cm/s\) away from mirror

explanation_plain_text:
= cm

or, I = = 40cm

or, 0 =

or,

d = 9

away from mirror

quest_title: Two charges \(\text{q}\)\({}_{1}\) = 2 \(\mu\)C and \(\text{q}\)\({}_{2}\) = -1 \(\mu\)C are kept at points \(\text{x}\) = 0 and \(\text{x}\) = 6 respectively. Electric potential will be zero at the points
explanation_txt:
\(V=\cfrac{q_{1}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{1}}-\cfrac{q_{2}}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0} r_{2}}\)

\(V=0\)

\(\therefore\, \cfrac{q_1}{4\pi \varepsilon_0 r_1} = \cfrac{q_2}{4\pi \varepsilon_0r_2}\)

Or, \(\cfrac{2 \mu \mathrm{C}}{x}=\cfrac{1 \mu \mathrm{C}}{6-x}\)

Or, \(x=12-2 x\)

Or, \(3 x=12 \Rightarrow x=4 \mathrm{cm}\)

explanation_plain_text:
Or,

Or,

ans2_plain_text: = 2 and = 9
ans3_plain_text: = 4 and = 12
ans4_plain_text: = -2 and = 2

quest_title: A wire of diameter 0.04cm & density 8000kg/m\({}^{3}\) is stretched by 80N. The length of wire to produce a noteof 840Hz is

\(\qquad=\cfrac{1}{2 \times 840} \sqrt{\cfrac{80}{\cfrac{\pi(0.04\times 10^{-2}
)^2\times8000}{4}}}\)
\(\qquad=0.168 \mathrm{m}=16.8 \mathrm{cm}\)

quest_title: A string of length \( 10cm \) is tied at two ends \( 8cm \) apart and is pulled to make it taut. The locus of point of maximum deflection is an ellipse of eccentricity:
explanation_txt:
Note that the length of string gives the length of major axis \( 2a \), and distance between ends give distance between foci, \( 2ae \). So, \(e = 8/10 = 4/5 \)

The figure below illustrates the situation. The fixed ends are \( S_1,S_2 \) and one of the point of "maximum deflection" is \(P\). You may see why \(A_1,A_2\) are other two such points, and also verify that \( PS_1 + PS_2 = A_1 A_2 = 10 \).

quest_title: \( \lim _ { x \rightarrow 1 } \cfrac { \log x } { x - 1 } = \)
explanation_txt:
\( \lim _ { x \rightarrow 1 } \cfrac { \log [ ( x - 1 ) + 1 ] } { x - 1 } = 1 \)

Since, \( \lim_ {x \to 0} \cfrac{\ln (x+1)}{x} = 1 \)

Or,

Using L-Hopital Rule:

\( \lim _ { x \rightarrow 1 } \cfrac { \log x } { x - 1 } = \lim _ { x \rightarrow 1 } \cfrac { \cfrac { 1 } { x } } { 1 } = 1 \)
explanation_plain_text:
Since,

Or,

Using L-Hopital Rule:

quest_title: \(\int \cfrac { \cos 2 x + 2 \sin ^ { 2 } x } { \cos ^ { 2 } x } d x =\)
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} \int \cfrac { \cos 2 x + 2 \sin ^ { 2 } x } { \cos ^ { 2 } x } d x & = \int \cfrac { 2 \left( \cos ^ { 2 } x + \sin ^ { 2 } x \right) - 1 } { \cos ^ { 2 } x } d x \\ & = \int \sec ^ { 2 } x d x = \tan x + c \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: A ball hits a vertical wall horizontally at 10m/s bounces back at 10 m/s
ans1_txt: There is no acceleration because \(10 \cfrac { m } { s } - 10 \cfrac { m } { s } = 0\)
ans2_txt: There may be an acceleration because its initial direction is horizontal
ans3_txt: There is an acceleration because there is a momentum change
ans4_txt: Even though there is no change in momentum there is a change in direction. Hence it has an acceleration
explanation_txt:
As the ball bounces back with same speed so change in momentum = 2 mv

and we know that force = rate of change of momentum

i.e. force will act on the ball so there is an acceleration.
question_plain_title: A ball hits a vertical wall horizontally at 10m/s bounces back at 10 m/s
explanation_plain_text:

and we know that force = rate of change of momentum

i.e. force will act on the ball so there is an acceleration.

quest_title: Maximum and minimum magnitudes of the resultant of two vectors of magnitudes P and Q are in the ratio 3:1. Which of the following relations is true?
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array} { l } { \text { According to problem } P + Q = 3 \text { and } P - Q = 1 } \\ { \text { By solving we get } P = 2 \text { and } Q = 1 \therefore \cfrac { P } { Q } = 2 \Rightarrow P = 2 Q } \end{array}\)

quest_title: The range of vision of a short sighted man is form 10cm to 20cm from eye. The range of vision while seeing distant object is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{u}=\infty, \mathrm{v}=-20 \mathrm{cm}\)

\(\mathrm{f}=-20 \mathrm{cm}\)

for near object:

\(\mathrm{u}=? \quad \mathrm{v}=-10 \mathrm{cm} \quad \mathrm{f}=-20 \mathrm{cm}\)

\(\mathrm{u}=\cfrac{\mathrm{fv}}{\mathrm{v}-\mathrm{f}}=\cfrac{(-20)(-10)}{-10+20}=20 \mathrm{cm}\)

\(\therefore\) range \(=20 \mathrm{cm}\) to infinity

explanation_plain_text:
for near object:

range to infinity

quest_title: The angle between the vectors (\( \overset{\rightarrow }{a}\) × \( \overset{\rightarrow }{b}\)) and (\( \overset{\rightarrow }{b}\)×\( \overset{\rightarrow }{a}\)) is :
question_plain_title: The angle between the vectors ( × ) and (×) is :

explanation_txt:
Let \[ I=\int _{0}^{1}\cfrac{dx}{[(a-b)x+b]^{2} } \]

Put \(t=(a-b)x+b\Rightarrow dt=(a-b)dx\)

As \(x=1\Rightarrow t=a\) and \(x=0\Rightarrow t=b\), then

\[I=\cfrac{1}{a-b} \int _{b}^{a}\cfrac{1}{t^{2} } dt \]

\[ =\cfrac{1}{(a-b)} \left[-\cfrac{1}{t} \right]_{b}^{a} \]

\[ =\cfrac{1}{(a-b)} \left(\cfrac{a-b}{ab} \right) \]

\[ =\cfrac{1}{ab} .\]

Put

As and , then

quest_title: A car moving with a velocity of 20 m/s. The driver sees a stationary truck at a distance of 100 m ahead. After some time `t' the driver applies brakes producing a retardation of 4 m/s\({}^{2}\) . The value of `t' avoid collision is
explanation_txt:
After applying brake

\(\begin{aligned} \mathrm{V}^{2} &=\mathrm{u}^{2}+2 \mathrm{as} \\ 0 &=20^{2}-2 \times 4 \mathrm{s} \\ 8 \mathrm{s} &=400 \\ \mathrm{s} &=50 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}\)

Distance travelled before applying brake

\(\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{S}^{\prime}=100-\mathrm{s}=100-50=50 \mathrm{m}} \\ {\therefore \text { Time }(\mathrm{t})=\cfrac{\mathrm{s}^{\prime}}{v}=\cfrac{50}{20}=2.5 \mathrm{sec}}\end{array}\)
question_plain_title: A car moving with a velocity of 20 m/s. The driver sees a stationary truck at a distance of 100 m ahead. After some time `t' the driver applies brakes producing a retardation of 4 m/s . The value of `t' avoid collision is
explanation_plain_text:
After applying brake

Distance travelled before applying brake
